text: now in the latest evidence of growing
tension between Britain and China the
foreign secretary
Dominic Robb has announced that the UK
is suspending its extradition treaty
with Hong Kong it's in response to
Beijing's imposition of a new national
security law which is aimed at stopping
any anti-communist activities in Hong
Kong the UK has already offered
residency rights to up to three million
Hong Kong residents but China has today
accused the UK of brutal meddling in its
internal affairs now back in 1997 the UK
handed back control of Hong Kong to
China after 150 years of British rule it
followed that joint declaration back in
1984 which said that Hong Kong's
economic and political freedoms would be
maintained for 50 years after the
handover
but now the UK along with the US and the
European Union is accusing Beijing of
undermining that principle of one
country two systems' they claim that the
new security law violates the terms of
the 1984 agreement especially in
relation to freedom of speech and Hong
Kong's
independent judicial system our
political editor Laura keansburg has the
story where the UK sent someone back to
this a new law in Hong Kong's tightened
China's grip on the streets and brought
fresh danger for those fighting for
democracy for more than 30 years if
someone now in the UK was suspected of a
crime Hong Kong could ask the government
to hand them over
under the extradition deal but now some
forms of protest could bring prosecution
not anymore and the government has
decided to suspend the extradition
treaty immediately and
there remains considerable uncertainty
about the way in which the new national
security law will be enforced I would
just say this the United Kingdom is
watching and the whole world is watching

imposed by Beijing has given the

semi-autonomous territory almost
overnight
Joshua Wong is the face of Hong Kong's

but since the introduction of the
national security law he believes he's

fears the authorities are building the

might be paulus his greatest fear is

freedom of the press many fear the new

pro-democracy activists say the very

publishers are really worried about the

the Communist Party says the national

we not only have to improve Hong Kong's
